thread.title_full: 9 comedians in dramatic roles - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 9 comedians in dramatic roles
text:
Universal Pictures Seth Rogen stars as Steve Wozniak in "Steve Jobs." If you love sad clowns, consider spending the weekend in a movie theater.
Not only does Seth Rogen portray Steve Wozniak in "Steve Jobs" — which gets released nation-wide on Friday — but two smaller films starring people known almost entirely for comedy will also be on select screens.
Stand-up comic Sarah Silverman stars in "I Smile Back," about a mother with clinical depression.
And “Saturday Night Live” alumna Kristen Wiig stars as a woman trying to have a baby with her gay best friend in “Nasty Baby.”
These are all very serious roles for people who are mostly known for being silly, though all have been in dramatic roles before (Rogen and Silverman in 2012's "Take This Waltz"; Wiig was also cast in a supporting role in "The Martian").
Here's a list of more people known primarily for comedy who've taken a leap into drama or action.
Jim Carrey in "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind"
Probably the most notable modern example of a comic going for broke in a flat-out drama.
Carrey plays a man who undergoes a medical procedure to have memories of his ex removed from his brain in Michel Gondry's classic.
The "Ace Ventura" star's lead performance was highly acclaimed, and The Onion A.V. Club named the film the Best of the 2000s.
Steve Carrell in "Foxcatcher"
Charles Sykes/Charles Sykes/Invision/AP Steve Carrell's gone dramatic for films like "Foxcatcher" and "Freeheld." Carrell has since gone further into dramatic performances, and some would argue his role in "The Office" is deeply sad, but this is his most notable laugh-free role to date.
Based on a true story, Carrell plays a philanthropist and wrestling coach who trains two brothers for the World Championships.
The role is decidedly darker than most of Carrell's prior fare, but he was rewarded with an Academy Award nomination for his performance.
Ben Stiller in "Greenberg"
Stiller is best known for being the straight man in the midst of all the crazies in most of his comedy roles, so it's not surprising to see him occasionally take the turn for drama. Think “Permanent Midnight.”
But in this still somewhat-funny Noah Baumbach dramedy, Stiller plays a disaffected man who returns to Los Angeles from New York to house sit for his brother.
Stiller was nominated for an Independent Spirit Award for the role.
Eddie Murphy in "Dreamgirls"
JOSHUA ROBERTS/REUTERS Eddie Murphy won a Golden Globe for "Dreamgirls." Many thought Murphy would win the Oscar for this role, and that it was one of his comedies that hurt him in the process.
In this musical, Murphy plays James (Thunder) Early, a performer who has an affair with one of the members of the girl group the film focuses on, who eventually falls into depression and drug abuse as his star fades.
Murphy won a Golden Globe for his portrayal of Early, but lost the Oscar, with many suspecting that his broad comedy film, "Norbit," which came out shortly after "Dreamgirls" hurt his chances.
Jennifer Aniston in "Cake"
While not a comedian, Aniston is primarily known for comedy on both television ("Friends") and in film ("Office Space" and "Horrible Bosses").
In this drama, Aniston plays a woman looking to come to terms with the death of her son and a friend.
Aniston was nominated for a Golden Globe for the role.
Adam Sandler in "Punch Drunk Love"
Jemal Countess/Getty Images When Adam Sandler strays from comedy, the critics tend to love it. Paul Thomas Anderson often uses funny people in his films, and the typically slapstick Sandler might be the best example.
Sandler plays a troubled man who falls in love while dealing with being blackmailed.
The "Jack and Jill" star scored a Golden Globe nomination for his performance.
Bill Murray in, well, most of his films
LUCAS JACKSON/REUTERS Perhaps no comedic actor has transitioned better to drama than Bill Murray. The "SNL" alum used the Wes Anderson comedy, "Rushmore" to transition into a second phase of his career where he largely played sad, aging men in more subtle, dramatic films.
His parts in further Anderson films have ranged from funny ("The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou") to depressing ("The Royal Tenenbaums") and other films like "Lost in Translation," "Hyde Park on Hudson," and "St. Vincent" have traversed this range.
Mike Myers in "Inglorious Basterds"
Most of Quentin Tarantino's film do the opposite of this list, in making typically stoic, dramatic actors look funny and cool.
However, the "Austin Powers" star's brief turn in a British general in Tarantino's rewriting of World Warr II history his mostly straight-laced.
Martin Short in "Inherent Vice"
As with "Punch Drunk Love," Paul Thomas Anderson uses a big comedy star's persona to his advantage in this stoner mystery.
Short plays a drug-addled dentist who leads James Brolin's character further on the run from a corrupt police force.
